abstract: Bank of America‘s not-so-surprising announcement on Friday that it is being bailed out by the federal government because of excessive losses at its new Merrill Lynch subsidiary raises a number of questions. The most significant one is this: What did Bank of America know and when did it know it? And why are Bank of America shareholders learning about the huge losses only now, after their shareholder vote on the Merrill deal?
lead_paragraph: Bank of America‘s not-so-surprising announcement on Friday that it is being bailed out by the federal government because of excessive losses at its new Merrill Lynch subsidiary raises a number of questions. The most significant one is this: What did Bank of America know and when did it know it? And why are Bank of America shareholders learning about the huge losses only now, after their shareholder vote on the Merrill deal?

headline.main: Did Bank of America Mislead Investors?
